intro: Josephia serra, commonly known as the Sierra Josephia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, which includes legumes, and is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, pea-like flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils and thrives in arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are compound, consisting of several small, oval-shaped leaflets, and it produces pods that contain seeds. Josephia serra is often found in desert scrub and chaparral habitats, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local wildlife.
